briefOverview: The Lord explains the chastening of the Saints, promises Zion’s eventual redemption, and gives instructions for gathering, lawful redress, and steadfast discipleship.
summary: The Lord states that the Saints’ afflictions have come partly as chastening for transgression but assures them of compassion, future gathering, and Zion’s permanence. He calls them to stand in holy places and describes the coming day when the veil is removed, the earth is renewed, enmity ceases, Satan loses power, and death and sorrow end, with hidden things revealed. He urges fearlessness, care for the soul, and constancy in seeking His face, warning that those who lose their savor are cast out. Through a parable of a nobleman, vineyard, and neglected tower, He rebukes sloth and discord and commands the redemption of His vineyard. He instructs the Saints to continue gathering, but not in haste, to purchase lands for Zion, and to follow wise, prepared procedures. He directs those scattered to importune the courts, governor, and president for redress under just constitutional principles, warning of divine judgment if rulers refuse mercy. Finally, He forbids selling the appointed storehouse, commands holding claim to appointed inheritances, and promises the Saints will build and enjoy the fruits thereof.
externalContext: This revelation is dated December 16, 1833, amid the expulsion of Latter-day Saints from Jackson County, Missouri, where they had attempted to establish “Zion.” Rising tensions with local Missourians over religion, politics, economics, and land led to violence, destruction of property, and forced removal. Leaders and members sought legal remedies in Missouri and contemplated means to regain lands. The references to the Constitution reflect the early American setting and the Saints’ appeal to civil law for protection. The call to “redeem Zion” soon informed efforts in 1834 commonly known as Zion’s Camp.
externalReferences: The chapter invokes Abraham’s sacrifice as a model of being tried (Genesis 22) and employs Jesus’s images of the “salt of the earth” and the “wheat and the tares” (Matthew 5:13; 13:24–30, 36–43), as well as His parable of the persistent widow and unjust judge (Luke 18:1–8). Its millennial and cosmic-renewal language parallels Isaiah’s peaceable kingdom (Isaiah 11:6–9), Peter’s description of the elements melting (2 Peter 3:10–12), and promises of transformation “in a moment” and being “caught up” (1 Corinthians 15:51–52; 1 Thessalonians 4:17), with consolation akin to God making all things new and removing death and sorrow (Revelation 21:4–5). It also echoes “Be still, and know that I am God” (Psalm 46:10) and vineyard-watchtower imagery reminiscent of Isaiah’s song of the vineyard (Isaiah 5:1–7).

sectionTitles.title: Gathering, lawful redress, and property counsel

practicalQuestions: Where do I see signs of contention or sloth that could weaken my community’s spiritual defenses, and how will I correct them?
How can I prepare spiritually and temporally to “stand in holy places” without acting in haste?
In what lawful, orderly ways can I seek redress against injustice while maintaining faith and patience?
What does it mean for me to retain my spiritual “savor,” and what practices help me avoid losing it?
How does the hope of millennial renewal and resurrection shape my courage to prioritize the life of the soul over fear for the body?
uncertainAreas: Identifying precise historical referents within the vineyard parable (e.g., who each character represents and which actions correspond to specific 1833 events) is not explicit in the text. The timing and sequencing of millennial details (e.g., no death, instant change) are presented programmatically but not fully defined. How universally to apply directions about purchasing specific lands and holding claims, beyond the 1833 Missouri context, requires caution.
